docs.lead_paragraph: It’s time for the federal government to step aside.
docs.abstract: Editorial calls on the federal government to end its ban of marijuana under the archaic Controlled Substances Act; argues states should be left to decide whether to legalize and regulate its use; contends while Congress is not currently ready to embrace legalization bills, there is a growing, bipartisan coalition of legislators who see it as a state issue; holds Pres Obama should take further measures in the meantime (Series: High Time).
docs.snippet: It’s time for the federal government to step aside.

docs.lead_paragraph: The sprinklers outside the California's state Capitol are off and the lawn is withering, the lemon- and cucumber-infused "water stations" at the state pension building are gone, and prison inmates are taking shorter showers while campers at some popular parks can't take them at all.

headline.main: California Can't Say if It's Meeting Drought Goal
headline.print_headline: California Can't Say if It's Meeting Drought Goal

docs.lead_paragraph: The adviser, Jonathan Gruber, a professor of economics at M.I.T., made a statement in 2012 that undercut arguments the Obama administration is now making about the Affordable Care Act.

headline.main: Ex-Obama Aide’s Statements in 2012 Clash With Health Act Stance
headline.print_headline: Ex-Aide’s Statements in 2012 Clash With Health Act Stance

docs.abstract: Jonathan Gruber, former Obama administration adviser on health policy, publicly stated in 2012 that consumers could not obtain insurance subsidies under the health care law if they lived in states that refused to establish their own insurance exchanges; videotaped comments contradict arguments the White House is now making in court that Congress always meant for subsidies to be available nationwide, in all states.
docs.snippet: The adviser, Jonathan Gruber, a professor of economics at M.I.T., made a statement in 2012 that undercut arguments the Obama administration is now making about the Affordable Care Act.

byline.original: By ROBERT PEAR and PETER BAKER

docs.lead_paragraph: From 2006 to 2010, 7.4 million women used infertility services, like an evaluation by a specialist, drug therapy or in vitro fertilization.

headline.main: Insurance Coverage for Fertility Treatments Varies Widely
headline.print_headline: Insurance Coverage for Fertility Treatments Varies Widely

docs.abstract: Tara Siegel Bernard Your Money column; few employers and insurers pay for fertility procedures, even as 7.4 million women used such services from 2006 to 2010; even when covered, restrictions imposed on who can qualify raise questions about who should be covered by infertility insurance.
docs.snippet: From 2006 to 2010, 7.4 million women used infertility services, like an evaluation by a specialist, drug therapy or in vitro fertilization.

docs.lead_paragraph: An Arkansas business owner was the face of a television ad critical of the Obama administration’s health care plan, but insurance companies were backers.

headline.main: Opaque System Obscures Support for Health Care Ad
headline.print_headline: Opaque System Obscures Support for Health Care Ad

docs.abstract: Television ad critical of Obama administration's health care plan points blame at Arkansas Sen Mark Pryor and features a small-business owner frustrated by what he called higher health care bills; Pryor, a Democrat, is considered one of the most vulnerable incumbents facing re-election this fall; ad is sponsored by National Federation of Independent Business but largest chunk of money comes from health insurance companies trying to repeal a health care tax.
docs.snippet: An Arkansas business owner was the face of a television ad critical of the Obama administration’s health care plan, but insurance companies were backers.

docs.lead_paragraph: At the federal level, Republicans should look to untapped areas for reform, like intellectual property and infrastructure.

headline.main: Lots of Paul Ryan’s New Report Is About State and Local Policy

docs.snippet: At the federal level, Republicans should look to untapped areas for reform, like intellectual property and infrastructure.

docs.lead_paragraph: Dennis Jones, owner of a superyacht that helped save a shipyard, says the spending that goes with a lavish lifestyle can do as much good as charity.

headline.main: Seeing a Supersize Yacht as a Job Engine, Not a Self-Indulgence
headline.print_headline: Seeing a Supersize Yacht as a Job Engine, Not a Self-Indulgence

docs.abstract: Paul Sullivan Wealth Matters column; Dennis M Jones, who makes no apologies about his luxury lifestyle, is encouraging other wealthy people to think about how their extravagant living could provide jobs, just as their charity helps those in need; Jones's $34 million yacht purchase helped save shipbuilder and hundred of jobs of people it employed.
docs.snippet: Dennis Jones, owner of a superyacht that helped save a shipyard, says the spending that goes with a lavish lifestyle can do as much good as charity.

docs.lead_paragraph: We’ve finally reached the point where the do-nothing, delay-everything Congress has reached its logical position.

headline.seo: Congress’s Next Big Idea? Sue Obama

docs.abstract: Timothy Egan Op-Ed column excoriates House Republicans and Speaker John Boehner for plot to sue Pres Obama over delayed implementation of part of Affordable Care Act that Republicans never supported in first place; says presidents throughout history have routinely delayed, modified or deferred enforcement of certain laws; faults Congress for their willingness to litigate rather than legislate.
docs.snippet: We’ve finally reached the point where the do-nothing, delay-everything Congress has reached its logical position.

docs.lead_paragraph: Figaro might not be getting married anytime soon. Mimi and Rodolfo might not fall in love in that cold Parisian garret. And Macbeth might never murder his way to the throne.

headline.print_headline: Lockout Looms as Met Contracts Set to Expire
